text.value: What novels are studied from the 1990s?

The first Harry Potter book was published 25 years ago. When it comes to whether a new generation will read the series, I wonder if it will go the way of To Kill a Mockingbird, The Catcher in the Rye, or The Great Gatsby: a classic that every American youth is required to read.

If Harry Potter ends up on English 101 syllabi, it's the epitome of its legacy, especially considering it was written for young adults and children. It would mean that educators think it’s important enough to assign as required reading to Gen Z.
Here’s an attempt at the turn-of-the-century literary canon (using data from college syllabi)
By Matt Daniels
Using 2 million syllabi from the past 10 years, I looked at which books from the 1990s are, today, widely assigned in college-level English Literature classes.
Here’s the #1, most-assigned book, which appears among 1,200 syllabi.
The Things They Carried wasn’t mega-popular when it was published, never even charting as a New York Times best seller.
But it did go on to be a Pulitzer Prize finalist. NPR said it’s now a staple of college and high school English classes, celebrated as one of the most important books about the experience of war.”

• Never charted as a New York Times Best Seller
  • 24th most frequently rated book on Goodreads
  • Pulitzer Prize Finalist

text.value: Today, The Things They Carried is pervasive in English literature curriculum. But understanding how it got there is even more important. There’s a lot of factors that influence educators’ decisions to assign a book.

Maybe it was heavily awarded. Maybe it’s had an outsized impact on culture. Maybe it represents an idea the next generation should know (in the case of The Things They Carried, it’s an account of the Vietnam war).
To help us understand the path a book takes to being a present-day classic, let’s add context for each book’s accolades:

• New York Bestseller: was a book commercially successful when it published?
  • Goodreads Ranking: it widely read today?
  • Literary Prizes: was it acclaimed by academics and critics?
Here’s that data for The Things They Carried:
Here's the #2 most-assigned book.
This is the most obscure book in our top 10, when we look at how often it’s rated on Goodreads. Woman Hollering Creek has 9,900 ratings on Goodreads; The Things They Carried has 286,000!
Woman Hollering Creek is ranked 1,971st in quantity of Goodreads ratings, the lowest among the 10 most-assigned ’90s fiction.

For Stanford’s Literary Lab, Digital Humanities scholar J.D. Porter points out a number of books that were never commercially popular, but have, over time, grown into a dominant force in the literary canon. One important example is the present-day classic Their Eyes Were Watching God by a Zora Neale Hurston.

“Before 1970, Zora Neale Hurston was the primary subject author in just 4 MLA articles, and all of her novels were out of print; none had sold more than 5,000 copies. It was famously the efforts of prestigious scholars and writers, especially Alice Walker, that recuperated her. And it worked: Today Hurston has over 700 MLA articles, and she has more Goodreads ratings than authors ranging from the canon that predated her…No doubt much of the public familiarity with her work derives from its now-common presence in classrooms, but this is precisely the point...a boost in prestige, driven by scholars and practitioners, and mediated through the classroom, led to a boost in popularity. The arc of escape from obscurity pulled her not just up but away.”
This story of Zora Neale Hurston ends with a really important point by Porter, “We do not merely study what people read; people read what we study.”
So in the case of Woman Hollering Creek, an obscure book today might be, over many generations, vaulted into the popular discourse.

text.value: Books like Harry Potter are cultural touchstones—we should expect that when books are widely-read, they’ll one day be studied. Yet that’s rarely the case.
With the exception of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone, few mega-popular books end up assigned in English Literature syllabi.

In 1951, Catcher in the Rye charted for 7 months as a New York Times Best Seller. Around the same time, Pulitzer Prize-winningThe Caine Mutiny, by Herman Wouk, would begin charting as well, and not leave the Best Seller List for 2.5 years.

There are countless examples of Caine Mutinys: Harry Potter-level popularity that eventually enter obscurity. Few songs from history are remembered by younger generations. Only a handful of movies will remain classics.
But with books, there’s the added forcing function of high school and college assigned readings, an opposing force to a natural fading of culture.
